messages.message:
Hey team, sharing this Trust Deed we received from NAB during our POC which is greater than 50MB. It doesn't look massively long or data heavy, I wonder if we can somehow lower the file size to fit out limits or increase our limits?

cc @Kaustubh (KD)

`pdfinfo 015_Royal\ Unit\ Trust.pdf` 
```Title:           Royal Property Trust.pdf
Author:          P792559
Producer:        Microsoft: Print To PDF
CreationDate:    Sat Aug 27 12:18:09 2022 CEST
ModDate:         Sat Aug 27 12:18:09 2022 CEST
Custom Metadata: no
Metadata Stream: no
Tagged:          no
UserProperties:  no
Suspects:        no
Form:            none
JavaScript:      no
Pages:           96
Encrypted:       no
Page size:       595.32 x 841.92 pts (A4)
Page rot:        0
File size:       86065246 bytes
Optimized:       no
PDF version:     1.7```
Seems generally normal at 96 pages, though filesize is huge.

Hypotheses: The PDF is likely large due to embedded *images or full fonts*.

1. *embedded images* 
3.5k images in there…
```pdfimages -list "015_Royal Unit Trust.pdf" > report.txt```
2.    embedded fonts
not the case, empty
```pdffonts 015_Royal\ Unit\ Trust.pdf 
name                                 type              encoding         emb sub uni object ID
------------------------------------ ----------------- ---------------- --- --- --- ---------```

Aggressive (non-lossless) compression can get it down to 9MB :wink:
```gs -sDEVICE=pdfwrite -dPDFSETTINGS=/screen    -dNOPAUSE -dBATCH -dQUIET    -sOutputFile=compressed.pdf "015_Royal Unit Trust.pdf"```
Unsure though if this is a strategy we want to introduce for large files, IMHO it requires some nuanced pre-checks (like do the page image sizes and number of pages correlate to the MBs?), …

Yeah this is a good question, ChatGPT has the following limits:
• General documents = 512mb per file
• Spreadsheets / CSVs = 50mb per file
Additionally, there are usage caps:
• Each end-user is capped at 10GB.
• Each organization is capped at 100GB
So we have smaller limits than for regular files (50mb) and spreadsheets (10mb). I think we should be revisiting these. cc: @Atinder / @Balaram
